chapter.title: Preparing for a Network Installation
chapter.para: A network installation using an installation server allows you to install &PRODUCT; on multiple systems using a network boot server. This way, all systems configured to do so will boot using an image provided by this server and start the installation program automatically.

note.para: Red Hat Satellite has the ability to automate the setup of a PXE server. See the Red Hat Satellite User Guide for more information.

chapter.para: A minimum of two systems is required for a network installation:

listitem.para: A server - a system running a DHCP server, a TFTP server to provide boot files, and an HTTP, FTP or NFS server which hosts the installation image. Theoretically, each of the servers can run on a different physical system; procedures in this section assume a single system runs all of them for simplicity.

A client - the system which you are installing &PRODUCT; to. When the installation begins, the client will query the DHCP server, obtain boot files from the TFTP server, and download the installation image from the HTTP, FTP or NFS server.

chapter.para: Unlike most other means of installation, no physical boot media is required to be plugged in the client (that is, the system you are installing into) in order to begin the installation. This chapter describes the steps you must take to prepare for network installations.
The following steps must be performed to prepare for a network installation:

listitem.para: Configure the network server (NFS, HTTPS, HTTP, or FTP) to export the installation tree or the installation ISO image. For procedures describing the configuration, see .
Configure the files on the tftp server necessary for network boot, configure DHCP, and start the tftp service on the PXE server. See for details.

important.para: The GRUB2 boot loader supports network boot from HTTP in addition to a tftp server. However, obtaining boot files (the kernel and initial ram disk for the installer) over this protocol is very slow and suffers a risk of timeout failures. Using a tftp server to provide the boot files is recommended.
This warning only applies to the kernel and initial ram disk (vmlinuz and initrd). Obtaining the installation source from an HTTP server does not carry this risk.

listitem.para: Boot the client (the system you want to install &PRODUCT; on) and start the installation.

note.para: The procedures in this chapter describe setting up a network boot server on a &PRODUCT; 7 system. For details about configuring network boot on earlier releases of &PRODUCT;, see the appropriate Installation Guide for that release.

section.title: Configuring Network Boot Services
section.para: After setting up a network server containing the package repositories to be used in the installation, the next step is to configure the PXE server itself. This server will contain files necessary to boot the &PRODUCT; and start the installation. Additionally, a DHCP server must be configured, and all necessary services must be enabled and started.

note.para: The network boot configuration procedure differs based on whether the AMD64/Intel 64 system you want to install &PRODUCT; on uses BIOS or UEFI. Consult your hardware's documentation to see which system is used on your hardware, and then follow the appropriate procedure in this chapter.
A separate procedure is provided for booting IBM Power Systems from a network location with the GRUB2 boot loader. See for details.

section.para: For more information on configuring a network boot server for use with headless systems (systems without a directly connected display, keyboard and mouse), see .

Without this option, the installation program will be unable to boot. For more information about boot options for Anaconda, see .

Finally, start and enable the services:

listitem.screen: # systemctl start dhcpd # systemctl enable dhcpd

listitem.para: The xinetd service, that manages the tftpd service:

section.para: After finishing this procedure, the PXE boot server is ready to serve PXE clients. You can now start the system you want to install &PRODUCT; on, select PXE Boot when prompted to specify a boot source, and start the network installation. For more information, see .

section.title: Configuring Network Boot for IBM Power Systems Using GRUB2

procedure.title: Configuring a Network Boot Server for IBM Power Systems Using GRUB2

step.para: Install the tftp-server package. To do this, enter the following command as root:
Allow incoming connections to the tftp service in the firewall:

note.para: The above command only enables access until the next server reboot. To allow access permanently, add the --permanent option. For more information about firewall configuration, see the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 Security Guide.

step.para: Create a GRUB2 network boot directory inside the tftp root:
step.screen: # grub2-mknetdir --net-directory=/var/lib/tftpboot Netboot directory for powerpc-ieee1275 created. Configure your DHCP server to point to /boot/grub2/powerpc-ieee1275/core.elf
step.para: Note the command's output, which informs you about which file needs to be configured as the filename in your DHCP configuration. This will become important further in the procedure.
Create a GRUB2 configuration file: /var/lib/tftpboot/boot/grub2/grub.cfg. The grub.cfg syntax is described in the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 System Administrator's Guide.
Below is an example configuration file:
step.screen:
set default=0 set timeout=5
echo -e "
Welcome to the Red Hat Enterprise Linux &PRODVER; installer!

"
menuentry 'Red Hat Enterprise Linux &PRODVER;' { linux grub2-ppc64/vmlinuz ro ip=dhcp inst.repo=http://10.32.5.1/mnt/archive/RHEL-7/&PRODVER;/Server/ppc64/os/ initrd grub2-ppc64/initrd.img }

important.para: The inst.repo= Anaconda option, shown in the example above, must always be used to specify the installation program's image as well as the installation source. Without this option, the installation program will be unable to boot. For more information about boot options for Anaconda, see .

step.para: Configure your DHCP server to use the boot images packaged with GRUB2. If you do not have one installed, see the Red Hat Enterprise Linux 7 Networking Guide for instructions.
A sample configuration in the /etc/dhcp/dhcpd.conf file might look like:

Adjust the sample parameters (subnet, netmask, routers, fixed-address and hardware ethernet) to fit your network configuration. Also note the filename parameter; this is the file name which was output by the grub2-mknetdir command earlier in the procedure.
Finally, start and enable the services:

listitem.screen: # systemctl start dhcpd # systemctl enable dhcpd

listitem.para: The xinetd service that manages the tftpd service:
listitem.screen: # systemctl start xinetd # systemctl enable xinetd

section.para: After finishing this procedure, the PXE boot server is ready to serve PXE clients. You can now follow the steps described in to boot your Power Systems client from this server.
Additional information about setting up network boot for IBM Power Systems clients can be found in the Netbooting on POWER - An Introduction at the IBM DeveloperWorks website.
